InstrumentControl API¶

The InstrumentControl API is the core of the Application GUI. It simplifies script development by abstracting local and remote instruments as simple Python objects and providing helper functions to handle all of the low-level communication with InstrumentManager instances.

The InstrumentControl object is essentially a wrapper for InstrumentManager, but simplifies the API by managing the communication to InstrumentManager instances on multiple machines. All of the resources from all of the connected InstrumentManager instances are cached locally and can be accessed using the API as if they were all local objects.

class InstrumentControl.InstrumentControl(**kwargs)[source]¶
Parameters:Logger (Logging.logger) – Logger instance if you wish to override the internal instance

InstrumentControl is a helper class that provides functionality to communicate with any number of local or remote InstrumentManager instances.

InstrumentControl simplifies the process of writing test instrument automation and control scripts. This is accomplished by abstracting the communication with InstrumentManager instances that contain the device interface code.

Note

InstrumentManager must be running on the local or remote machine that you are trying to connect to. InstrumentControl.startWaitManager() can be used to spawn a new process of InstrumentManager.

addManager(address, port=None)[source]¶

Connect to a manager instance at the given address and port. If the connection is successful, the remote resources are automatically added to the pool of resources using refreshManager()

Parameters:
  • address (str) – IP Address or Hostname
  • port (int) – Port
Returns:

True if manager found, False if connection failed
addResource(address, controller, ResID, VendorID=None, ProductID=None)[source]¶

Create a managed resource within a controller object

If controller is not a valid controller on the remote manager instance, or if the controller does not support manually adding resources, this function will return False.

Note

Controllers that rely on system resources such as VISA or serial can only communicate with devices that are known to the system. Controllers that have no way to scan or enumerate devices depend on this function to make it aware of the device. An example of this is a CAN bus-based Controller, which must know a device address before communication can be established.

Parameters:
  • address (str) – IP Address of manager
  • controller (str) – Name of controller to attach new resource
  • ResID (str) – Resource Identifier
  • VendorID (str) – Vendor Identifier for automatic model loading
  • ProductID (str) – Product Identifier for automatic model loading
Returns:

bool - True if success, False otherwise
cacheManager(address)[source]¶

Update the local cache of resources from a given Manager

Note

Use addManager() to establish a connection to a manager before calling this function.

Parameters:address (str) – IP Address to check
Returns:True unless there is no existing connection to address
cacheProperties(res_uuid=None)[source]¶

Refresh the cached property dictionary for a given resource. If no Resource UUID is provided, all resources properties will be updated.

Note

Properties should be refreshed when loading a new Model for a resource.

Parameters:res_uuid (str) – Unique Resource Identifier (UUID)
Returns:dict - updated resource properties

Returns:RpcClient object or None if no model is loaded for the resource

getInstrument_list()[source]¶

Get a list of RpcClient objects for all resources with models loaded

Note

This function opens a socket to every known instrument with a Model loaded. This could use a lot of system resources both locally and on remote InstrumentManagers if you don’t need them.

Returns:list of RpcClient objects
getInstrument_model(model_number)[source]¶

Get a list of RpcClient objects for resources with the given model number.

Note

Only resources that have a model loaded will report a model number.

Returns:list of RpcClient objects
getInstrument_serial(serial_number)[source]¶

Get a RpcClient object for the resource with the given serial number.

Note

Only resources that have a model loaded will report a serial number.

Returns:RpcClient object
getInstrument_type(d_type)[source]¶

Get a list of RpcClient objects for resources with the given device type.

Note

Only resources that have a model loaded will report a device type.

Returns:list of RpcClient objects
getManager(address)[source]¶

Get an InstrumentManager object for the host at address. Object returned is an common.rpc.RpcClient object that is linked to a remote InstrumentManager instance.

Note

This will always return an common.rpc.RpcClient object, even if the InstrumentManager instance is on the local machine.

Parameters:address (str) – IP Address of manger
Returns:common.rpc.RpcClient object or None if there is no existing connection to address

getResources(address=None)[source]¶

Get a listing of all cached resources from the given address or from all InstrumentManager instances.

Note

getResources will not trigger a refresh on the InstrumentManager, so resources returned may not be valid

Parameters:address (str) – IP Address of host (optional)
Returns:dict of tuples - { Resource UUID: (address, controller, resourceID, VID, PID) }

loadModel(res_uuid, modelName=None, className=None)[source]¶

Signal the remote InstrumentManager to load a model for a given resource. The InstrumentManager will attempt to identify a compatible model to load automatically. To force load a particular model, provide a modelName and className.

modelName must be an importable module on the remote system. The base folder used to locate the module is the models folder.

On startup, the InstrumentManager will attempt to load models for all resources automatically. This function only needs to be called to override the default model. unloadModel() must be called before loading a new model for a resource.

Note

If the import fails on the remote InstrumentManager, an exception will be logged (on the remote system), but this function will return False with no other indication.

Example:

instr.loadModel('360ba14f-19be-11e4-95bf-a0481c94faff', 'Tektronix.Oscilloscope.m_DigitalPhosphor', 'm_DigitalPhosphor')
Parameters:
  • res_uuid (str) – Unique Resource Identifier (UUID)
  • modelName (str) – Model package (Python module)
  • className (str) – Class Name
Returns:

bool - True if successful, False otherwise
managerRunning(address, port=None)[source]¶

Check if an InstrumentManager instance is running. Attempts to open a socket to the provided address and port.

Parameters:
  • address (str) – IP Address or Hostname
  • port (int) – Port
Returns:

True if running, False if not running
refreshManager(address=None)[source]¶

Force the remote InstrumentManager to refresh all of the controllers and enumerate any new resources.

Note

Use addManager() to establish a connection to a manager before calling this function.

Parameters:address (str) – IP Address or Hostname
Returns:True unless there is no existing connection to address
removeManager(address)[source]¶

Disconnect from the manager instance at address and purge all cached resources from that host.

Parameters:address (str) – IP Address of manger
Returns:True unless there is no existing connection to address
removeResource(res_uuid)[source]¶

Remove a managed resource from a remote controller.

Unlike addResource(), this function will find the IP Address and controller given res_uuid. If the resource cannot be found in the cache, this function will return False.

Parameters:res_uuid (str) – Unique Resource Identifier (UUID)
Returns:bool - True if resource was removed, False otherwise
startManager()[source]¶

Start a local instance of InstrumentManager using subprocess.Popen().

No attempt is made to check whether an InstrumentManager process is already running. The default behavior for :class:’InstrumentManager’ is to exit when the port is already in use.

See :class:’InstrumentManager’ documentation for more information.

Note

This function does not block! If the InstrumentManager instance is not fully initialized before attempting to connect to it, timeouts will occur.

startWaitManager(timeout=10.0)[source]¶

Start a local instance of InstrumentManager using subprocess.Popen(). This function will block until the manager is fully initialized.

See startManager() for more.

Parameters:timeout (float) – Maximum number of seconds to wait before timeout occurs
Returns:Nothing
stopManager(address, port=None)[source]¶

Send a stop signal to a manager instance running on a local or remote machine.

Note

InstrumentManager cannot be restarted once it is stopped

Parameters:
  • address (str) – IP Address or Hostname
  • port (int) – Port
Returns:

Nothing
unloadModel(res_uuid)[source]¶

Signal the remote InstrumentManager to unload the currently loaded model for a given resource. This function must be called before loadModel().

Parameters:res_uuid (str) – Unique Resource Identifier (UUID)
Returns:bool - True if successful, False otherwise
